title: What was Esdaile's belief in the "vital agent" and why was it important for his investigation into Animal Magnetism?
first_phrase: In the preceding paragraphs, the writer defends the investigation of animal magnetism by enlightened individuals who have witnessed its effects. The author argues that their experiences are valuable in understanding the phenomena of nature. In the last 200 tokens, the writer discusses James Esdaile's belief in the "vital agent" and how his experiences led him to adopt the fluid theory as an explanation for the effects produced by his method. However, Esdaile did not investigate the psychic and cosmic aspects of animal magnetism. The author notes that Esdaile's specialism differed from that of modern hypnotists in that he believed in knowing everything about his field. Esdaile's writings suggest that he was honest, and he expected what he said to be believed.
content: He was a Hypnotist, if we use that name as a general term, but he was a specialist in Mesmerism, just as Liebeault and Bernheim are specialists in Suggestion; but his specialism differed in kind from that of our modern hypnotists, in that he did not think that what he did not know is not worth knowing. It is impossible to read any of his writings and not feel that he is transparently honest and straightforward, and that he therefore expects what he says to be believed. He tells us that what he relates "may be taken as correct, otherwise healthy senses, a plain, direct understanding, careful observation, long experience, and every precaution against deception are so many snares, and one might as well be a polypus as a human being." He says:- "When one person is made the exclusive object of another's attention for certain lengths of time, surprising effects have ensued, which are now called the mesmeric phenomena. I can only imagine this to be the effect of an active upon a passive nervous system; the passive nerves and brain being invaded and occupied by the active, will-impelled nervous fluid of the agent."
last_phrase: In conclusion, Esdaile was a pioneer in the field of mesmerism, providing valuable insights into the workings of the nervous system and the transfer of vital energy between individuals. His frank and straightforward approach to his subject matter inspires credibility, making his writings valuable contributions to our understanding of the mesmerism phenomenon.
